name: C#
description: C# is our language of choice. It's strongly-typed, blends functional and object-oriented programming and works on all the OS we need to support.

name: TypeScript
description: TypeScript is our default choice for running code in the browser. It's strongly-typed and smoothes out the rough bits of JavaScript.

name: Go
description: Go is the natural language to use when writing cloud native software. But it is now possible to achieve good results in C# anyway.

name: Java 8
description: Redgate purchased Flyway, written in Java. We have navigated away from older JVM now that LTS has finally moved on.

name: Java 17
description: Redgate purchased Flyway, written in Java. We now use version 17 as is LTS and now fundamental to our Flyway strategy (we ship v21 but are using v17 language features and changing is a breaking change to the API)

name: Java 25
description: Redgate purchased Flyway, written in Java. 25 is the next LTS and we should seriously consider migrating once its stable.

name: Bash
description: Bash is our default choice for scripting internal tools. Everyone should be familiar with the Bash toolkit.

name: Python
description: Python is the most popular language for Machine Learning due to its extensive libraries, frameworks and data science community support. Teams starting new projects that involve AI/ML should default to Python, especially if model training is needed. When used as a scripting tool, Python provides a powerful language for gluing components together. We encourage trialling Python when the alternative would be a large Bash script (caveated by why isn't it easy to write a Bash script?).

name: PowerShell
description: Don't use PowerShell for new projects - prefer Bash.

name: .NET 8
description: .NET 8 is the latest LTS version of .NET, supported until November 10, 2026. It is cross-platform and a great choice for desktop, web and cloud-based applications.

name: Web API (ASP.NET Core)
description: ASP.NET Core Web API for building RESTful APIs on .NET

name: React
description: React makes it painless to create interactive UIs.

name: Electron
description: Electron has proved itself for developing web-based desktop products. It's our default choice for new desktop-based applications.

name: WinForms
description: Don't use WinForms for new projects - prefer Electron.

name: WPF
description: Don't use WPF for new projects - prefer Electron.

name: Object–relational mappers (ORMs)
description: Unless working with a large number of simple entities (or support for several different DB Backends), prefer writing SQL directly or using a lightweight object mapper such as Dapper.

name: Blazor
description: Blazor is super exciting. It means we might get to leverage our existing C# skills in the browser. However, we are making good progress standardizing on React, so we're putting this on hold. (see discussion to upgrade)

name: Razor Pages
description: Razor Pages can make coding page-focused scenarios easier and more productive than using controllers and views. We have chosen to adopt React instead.

name: MVC (Views)
description: MVC Views are a way to build web front ends, built ontop of MVC controllers. We have chosen to adopt React instead.

name: Project Lombok
description: Project Lombok is a Java code enhancement for introducing a set of tools to reduce boiler plating and increase developer efficiency and allowing for a more C# style of coding to help on-board new developers from the wider Red Gate environment

name: jUnit 4
description: Test framework for Java code

name: Visual Studio
description: Visual Studio is our default IDE for developing in C#. We get the Enterprise edition via our MSDN subscription.

name: Rider
description: Many teams use Rider instead of Visual Studio for their development. We have licenses for it.

name: VS Code
description: A free lightweight IDE. Our text editor of choice.

name: IntelliJ
description: An IDE for Java with a wide range of tools and plugins avalible. We have licenses for it.

name: GitHub
description: All development should use GitHub.

name: TeamCity
description: New projects must use GitHub Actions. We want to phase out TeamCity by late 2025.

name: Circle CI
description: New projects must use GitHub Actions. We want to phase out Circle CI by September 2025.

name: Azure DevOps
description: New projects must use GitHub Actions instead of TeamCity. We want to phase out Azure Devops by early 2026.

name: GitHub Actions
description: GitHub Actions is our default CI/CD system. See this internal post for more details.

name: Redgate.Build
description: Redgate.Build is our own PowerShell based build scripts. Over time it's become complicated and we wouldn't recommend it for new projects.

name: Terraform
description: Used for automating infrastructure provisioning.

name: Application Insights
description: All applications should use Application Insights as the default developer telemetry platform (incl. feature usage and error reporting).

name: OpenTelemetry
description: The industry has converged on this as the framework of choice for telemetry, all major vendors, including Application Insights, support the OpenTelemetry Protocol (OTLP). We should migrate away from the native AppInsights SDK.

name: JDBC
description: Database connectivity for Java.

name: Flyway
description: Our default tool for migrating database schemas.

name: WSL 2
description: Windows Subsystem for Linux should be installed on every development machine

name: SignalR
description: SignalR is our default choice for push-functionality.

name: Hashicorp Vault
description: We recommend Hashicorp Vault for storing secrets.

name: Keepass files in GitHub
description: Use a password manager (or Vault) instead.

name: Docker
description: Docker should be used as the default containerisation technology. Used for building, testing and deployment.

name: gRPC
description: gRPC is a high-performance RPC framework which we may investigate for high-volume data collection (for example, SQL Monitor).

name: Snyk
description: We use Snyk to scan for known vulnerabilities in our products' dependencies.

name: Virtualbox based Vagrant boxes
description: Use Docker instead where possible. UI and manual testing may still use Virtualbox.

name: Amazon Web Services
description: AWS is our default cloud provider. It should be the default choice for any SaaS offerings. Any long-lived services should be deployed into our AWS landing zone which gives appropriate controls to satisfy InfoSec requirements.

name: Azure
description: Azure should only be used for replicating customer environments.

name: Google Cloud Platform
description: GCP should only be used for replicating customer environments.

name: Redgate Platform
description: Redgate Platform was an early project to try and bring all of our products under a common architecture. It should no longer be used.

name: Kubernetes
description: K8S is the undeniable winner of orchestration tools.

name: SQL Server as backing store
description: When a product needs to store more complex data than it can fit in a flat file, we ask the customer for a SQL DB.

name: PostgreSQL as backing store
description: If there's a very good reason to use a lightweight/free database engine, we should choose Postgres.

name: Multi-OS (Windows, Linux x64 (.NET supported versions), macOS)
description: All three must be supported platforms.

name: Virtual Machines
description: Prefer using lightweight Docker containers.

name: CLIs
description: Product should, where possible, expose functionality via a CLI.

name: RESTful APIs
description: A REST architectural style is our default choice for building web APIs. Deviations can be made when it makes sense to do so.

name: Containerised products
description: Where possible, all new products should be built to be containerised. We should ship the Mac/Linux versions of our products inside Docker containers.

name: Infrastructure as code
description: Infrastructure should be provisioned through code rather than manually (except for ad-hoc testing)

name: Automated code style settings
description: Codebases should be formatted consistently. Automated code-style settings achieve this without fuss.

name: Static code analysis (linters)
description: Static code analysis is invaluable for automatically checking for problems in code. We use ESLint for JS and Roslyn-based analyzers for .NET. We also experimented with SonarQube but our implementation wasn't giving us confidence.

name: Semantic Versioning
description: We should use semver for all our versioning needs unless there's a compelling reason not to.

name: Database Agnosticism
description: We aim for feature parity between products that support different database engines.

name: Feature Flags
description: Feature Flags are a great technique for minimizing long-lived feature branches. Our recommendation is to focus on simplicity - if you find yourself writing substantial code to support Feature Flags, consider using a third-party solution.

name: Continuous delivery
description: Products should be ready for release at any time.

name: Continuous Deployment
description: We'd like to evaluate technology that increases our deployment frequency, with a view to getting value into the hands of our users as quickly as possible.

name: Build inside Docker containers
description: We should reduce build dependencies by building and testing our products inside containers. This is a pre-requisite for performing builds on cloud based CI providers.

name: AI/ML
description: AI/ML are becoming commoditized. Off-the-shelf software is available for predictive modelling, text analysis, anomaly detection and much more.

name: Automation/Low-code solutions
description: Remote is driving a digital transformation across industries. Low-code solutions, such as Power Apps, allow organizations to modernize these processes.

name: Git Ops
description: The core idea of GitOps is having a Git repository that always contains declarative descriptions of the infrastructure currently desired in the production environment and an automated process to make the production environment match the described state in the repository. If you want to deploy a new application or update an existing one, you only need to update the repository - the automated process handles everything else. It’s like having cruise control for managing your applications in production. Read more, currently being trialled for Platform Hosted

name: DAPR
description: DAPR (Distributed Application Runtime - https://dapr.io/) is an abstraction layer for use in a distributed application, currently being trialled by Platform for both Hosted and Enterprise. It is used to standardise how to communicate external systems in such a way we can uniformly add features through the DAPR sidecar

name: Asynchronous state management in React
description: Asynchronous state management in React should be delegated to a third-party framework such as react-query. This avoids manual management of promises' states (e.g. loading/errors), and allows using suspense and error boundaries in modern React.

name: OpenAPI
description: The OpenAPI Specification is a specification language for HTTP APIs that provides a standardized means to define your API to others. You can quickly discover how an API works, configure infrastructure, generate client code, and create test cases for your APIs.

name: Async API
description: https://www.asyncapi.com/ is an open-Source tools to easily build and maintain your event-driven architecture. All powered by the AsyncAPI specification, claims to be the industry standard for defining asynchronous APIs.

name: Vite
description: Vite is a front end tooling that can replace webpack. It is faster and improves the developer experience.

name: Webpack
description: Webpack is a build tool, it's main purpose is to bundle JavaScript files for usage in a browser.

name: RestSharp
description: RestSharp is a simple, open-source REST and HTTP API client for .NET. It's an easy-to-use and flexible tool that allows developers to interact with HTTP services from .NET applications
